LEAD: Scientists are scheduled to begin a series of experiments high over Australia Jan. 15 to test the theory that storm clouds act as funnels to carry chemicals from the troposphere, 7 to 10 miles above the earth's surface, to the stratosphere.

Scientists are scheduled to begin a series of experiments high over Australia Jan. 15 to test the theory that storm clouds act as funnels to carry chemicals from the troposphere, 7 to 10 miles above the earth's surface, to the stratosphere.

Philip Russell of NASA's Ames Research Center, the project manager, said the $10 million study should provide important clues about the depletion of the atmosphere's ozone layer. Scientists around the world are concerned that the layer, which acts as a shield against cancer-causing ultraviolet rays from the sun, is being destroyed by chlorofluorocarbons, chemicals widely used in refrigeration and for other purposes.
Scientists have not yet learned how these and other chemicals reach the upper atmosphere, nor have they agreed on what steps should be taken to protect the ozone.

The study will be carried out on a month-long series of flights by airplanes equipped to fly at high altitude and carrying instruments to measure ozone, Mr. Russell said. The planes will take off from Darwin on the northern coast of Australia, an area known for its concentration of giant cumulonimbus clouds.

Mr. Russell said some scientists think that a large percentage of the chemicals reaching the stratosphere may be funnelling up through the clouds over northern Australia. If that is the case, they still will have to learn why a large hole in the ozone was found recently in the ozone over Antarctica instead of over Australia.
